summary: This document appears to be an FBI interview summary (302) with a former Palm Beach Police Chief, detailing the initial investigation into Jeffrey Epstein, including police surveillance, victim statements, Epstein's donations to the police department, and interactions with the State Attorney's office. It also describes political and social context, including statements from Donald Trump and mentions of Prince Andrew.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central subject of the police investigation for alleged sexual misconduct with minors. He made significant donations to the Palm Beach Police Department.

persons.name: Jerry Goldsmith
persons.context: Described by the interviewee as someone Epstein sent to speak to the police, claiming the girls were 'just prostitutes' and the cases were minor.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Reportedly called the Palm Beach Police to thank them for investigating Epstein, claimed he threw Epstein out of his club, and advised police to focus on Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Prince Andrew
persons.context: Mentioned as a fixture in Palm Beach who had no protection while there, implying his connection to Epstein's social circle.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Referenced by Donald Trump as Epstein's 'operative' who is 'evil' and whom police should focus on.

connections.description: Epstein sent Goldsmith to speak to the police chief to downplay the allegations, characterizing the girls as prostitutes.
Trump stated he was around Epstein once when teenagers were present and that he had thrown Epstein out of his club.
Trump identified Maxwell as Epstein's 'operative,' directing law enforcement attention toward her.
Prince Andrew is noted as a fixture in Palm Beach, placing him within Epstein's social orbit.

events.title: Initial Tip and Surveillance
events.description: A tip came in about attractive women coming and going from Epstein's house. Police surveillance followed, stopping two adult women who said they worked for him.

events.title: First Victim Comes Forward
events.description: The stepmother of the first victim called police, leading to an interview where the victim stated she was not the only one involved.

events.title: Police Case Presented to State Attorney
events.description: Palm Beach PD built a case, including observations of prepubescent girls, and presented it to the State Attorney's office, which declined to prosecute, citing victim credibility issues.

events.title: Epstein's Donations to PBPD
events.description: Epstein donated $40,000 for a security footage review machine and wrote a $90,000 check for a fingerprint machine around the time the first victim came forward.

events.title: Harassment by Private Investigators
events.description: After the state case died, private investigators began harassing the police chief, pulling officers' trash, and making concerning statements about safety.

events.title: Referral to FBI and Plea Deal Discussions
events.description: The case was referred to the FBI. The interviewee later heard about discussions of a plea deal or non-prosecution agreement that included a victim fund.

events.title: Trump's Call to Police
events.description: Donald Trump called the Palm Beach Police to thank them for investigating Epstein, claiming he had ejected Epstein from his club and that people in New York knew he was 'disgusting.'

keyFacts: Epstein made substantial donations to the Palm Beach Police Department ($40,000 and a $90,000 check) around the time the first victim came forward.
The State Attorney's office declined to prosecute the state-level case, questioning victim credibility and allegedly leaking information to the defense.
Donald Trump contacted police during the investigation, stated he had thrown Epstein out of his club, and identified Ghislaine Maxwell as a key target.
Private investigators harassed the police chief after the state case collapsed, including going through officers' trash.
The document suggests high-level interference or disinterest, with the State Attorney initially claiming never to have heard of Epstein and later citing 'interest from higher up.'
